article.name: SecurityCoach Quickstart Guide
article.title: SecurityCoach Quickstart Guide
article.body:
Tip:Join the KnowBe4 Community! In the community, you can connect, share knowledge, and collaborate on new ideas with other admins, partners, and employees. For more information, see our KnowBe4 Community Guide.

In this guide, you’ll learn how to set up SecurityCoach in four easy steps. By following these steps, you can start detecting risky activity and coach your users in real time.

Important:If your organization uses user provisioning, make sure your organization is using the latest version to get the most out of SecurityCoach. For more information about user provisioning, see our Active Directory Integration (ADI) Configuration Guide or our SCIM Configuration Guide.

As you complete each step, you can mark it as complete in the SecurityCoach Setup section of your dashboard. To view your dashboard, navigate to SecurityCoach > Dashboard.

If you would like more detailed instructions, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Step One: Integrate Vendors

SecurityCoach is integrated automatically with KSAT, but you can also set up integrations with your other security vendors. Once you set up these integrations, you can begin monitoring for risky activities using the data from your security vendors.

To set up your security vendor integrations, click Integrate Vendors on the SecurityCoach Setup task list or navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations. Then, configure the integrations that you would like to use in your organization. For detailed instructions on setting up vendor integrations, see our Vendor Integration Guides.

Step Two: Add Delivery Method (Optional)

Next, we recommend setting up a delivery method to send SecurityTips to your users. SecurityTips include a text notification and media to coach your users about risky activity and how to avoid it in the future.

Email is automatically available as a delivery method. However, we recommend adding Slack, Microsoft Teams, or Google Chat to coach your users where they communicate most.

To get started, click Add Delivery Method on the SecurityCoach Setup task list or navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Delivery Setup. Then, select the delivery method you would like to set up. For detailed instructions, see our Slack Integration Guide for SecurityCoach, Microsoft Teams Integration Guide for SecurityCoach, or Google Chat Integration Guide with SecurityCoach.

Step Three: Review Rule Detections (Optional)

SecurityCoach provides system detection rules for each security vendor. Detection rules identify what risky activity you would like to track using the data provided by your integrated vendors.

These detection rules are enabled automatically, but you can also create custom detection rules if needed. For more information about detection rules, see our Creating and Managing Detection Rules article.

We recommend reviewing your top detection rules so that you prioritize what risky activities to target with your real-time coaching campaigns.

Note:Enabled detection rules do not automatically send SecurityTips to your users. You must create a real-time coaching campaign to send SecurityTips.

You can review your Top Detection Rules in the Detection Rules Report. To view this report, click Review Detection Rules on the SecurityCoach Setup task list or navigate to SecurityCoach > Reports > Detection Rules Report > Report. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview article.

Step Four: Create a Real-Time Coaching Campaign

Finally, you can create a real-time coaching campaign. Real-time coaching campaigns send SecurityTips to users when risky activity is detected on their devices.

To create a real-time coaching campaign, click Create Real-Time Coaching Campaigns on the SecurityCoach Setup task list or navigate to SecurityCoach > Real-Time Coaching. On the Real-Time Coaching page, you can create real-time coaching campaigns based on our recommendations or create your own custom real-time coaching campaigns.

Tip:If you're not ready to coach your entire organization, you can create a test mode campaign to see how your campaign will perform before you begin coaching your users.

For more information about setting up real-time coaching campaigns, see our Creating and Managing Real-Time Coaching Campaigns article.

images.alt:
This screenshot displays the four-step **SecurityCoach Setup** checklist interface, preceded by the instructional text: "Go beyond security awareness training by coaching your users in real time. Complete each step below to get started."

The setup is organized into an accordion structure, with the first step expanded:

1.  **Integrate Vendors:**
    *   **Status:** Marked "Incomplete" (in a dark grey pill label).
    *   **Expanded Content:** Provides a description of the necessary integration process.
    *   **Resources:** A dedicated section links to "Vendor Integration Guides" (blue hyperlink).
    *   **Action Buttons:** Two stacked buttons are visible on the right:
        *   Primary Action (Blue): "Integrate Vendors"
        *   Secondary Action (Highlighted with an orange box): "✓ Mark as Complete"

The subsequent three steps are collapsed and marked "Incomplete":

2.  **Add Delivery Method (Optional)**
3.  **Review Detection Rules (Optional)**
4.  **Create Real-Time Coaching Campaigns**

The image displays a web application interface focused on **Security Vendor Integrations** within a configuration area.

**Context and Navigation:**

1.  **Page Header:** The primary title is "Security Vendor Integrations."
2.  **Top Navigation:** The main navigational breadcrumb shows the "Setup" tab as actively selected. Other tabs include Dashboard, Real-Time Coaching, Detection Rules, SecurityTips, and Reports.
3.  **Setup Submenu (Left Panel):** The current view is highlighted as "Security Vendor Integrations." Sub-sections available are "User Mapping Setup" and "Delivery Setup."
4.  **Instructional Text:** An information alert provides a link for assistance: "For instructions on setting up security vendor integrations, see our Vendor Integration Guides."

**Main Content Sections:**

**1. Active Integrations:**
This section displays security vendors successfully connected and configured.
*   **Structure:** Two vendor tiles are present: Malwarebytes and Microsoft Cloud App Security.
*   **Status Indicators:** Both tiles feature a large green checkmark badge, indicating successful integration status.
*   **Call-to-Action (CTA):** Each active tile provides an "Edit" button for modification of the existing setup.

**2. Available Integrations:**
This section lists security vendors available for initial configuration.
*   **Structure:** Five vendor tiles are displayed in a grid format.
*   **Vendors Listed:** Carbon Black, Cisco Secure Email, Cisco Umbrella, CODE42, and CrowdStrike.
*   **Call-to-Action (CTA):** Each available vendor tile includes a blue "Configure" button to initiate the setup process.

This image displays the **Delivery Setup** screen within a web application's configuration interface, specifically focusing on notification channel management for "SecurityCoach."

**Navigation and Context:**
*   The primary horizontal navigation bar includes "Dashboard," "Real-Time Coaching," "Detection Rules," "SecurityTips," "Setup" (currently selected), and "Reports."
*   The left-hand sidebar menu, nested under the main "Setup" area, shows three configuration sections: "Security Vendor Integrations," "User Mapping Setup," and "Delivery Setup." "Delivery Setup" is highlighted in blue, indicating the active view.

**Main Content Area:**
*   **Header:** "Delivery Setup."
*   **Instructional Text:** "Configure delivery channels for your SecurityCoach notifications" (accompanied by an info icon).
*   The body features four integration cards detailing the configuration status of potential delivery channels:

| Channel/Platform | Logo/Icon | Status Text | Status Indicator |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Slack | Slack logo | Not Configured | Red 'X' |
| Microsoft Teams | Microsoft Teams logo | Not Configured | Red 'X' |
| (Unlabeled Chat) | Generic green chat icon | Not Configured | Red 'X' |
| Email | '@ Email' icon | Configured | Green Checkmark |

This image displays a security analytics dashboard titled "Detection Rules Report," summarizing rule detection metrics over a selected time frame ("Last 90 Days," indicated by a dropdown menu in the upper right).

The report is structured into three main sections:

1.  **Detection Rules Overview (Key Metrics):**
    *   **Total Events:** 4,975 (Icon: Crosshairs/Target)
    *   **Rule Detections:** 800 (Icon: Insect/Bug)
    *   **Users Involved:** 20 (Icon: Single Person)
    *   **Users with Multiple Rule Detections:** 20 (Icon: Person with Plus sign)

2.  **Top Detection Rules (Bar Chart - Highlighted in Orange):**
    *   This horizontal bar chart ranks the top rules based on the **User Count** (X-axis, scaled 0 to 22).
    *   The Y-axis lists the rule names. All displayed rules show approximately 19-20 users detected.
    *   **Examples of rules listed:** Cryptomining Detected by Zs..., Custom Gmail Detection Rule, External Email Forwarding D..., Organization Sensitive Data..., Copyright Infringement Dete..., Custom Zscaler Detection Rule, Spamming Detected.

3.  **Top Users by Rule Detections (Data Table):**
    *   This table ranks users based on the number of rule detections.
    *   **Columns:** Email (blurred for privacy) and Rule Detection Count.
    *   The top ten entries all show a **Rule Detection Count of 40**.

This document describes a user interface (UI) screen centered on managing security awareness training campaigns. The screen is divided into two primary sections: Recommendations and Campaign Management.

### Section 1: Real-Time Coaching Recommendations

This section features a horizontal grid of risk-categorized cards designed to prompt the creation of new coaching campaigns.

*   **Header:** Title "Real-Time Coaching Recommendations" with an instruction: "Select a detection rule category to begin creating a real-time coaching campaign."
*   **Primary Action Button:** A persistent, global call-to-action button is located in the top-right corner: **+ Create Real-Time Coaching Campaign**.
*   **Recommendation Cards (4 visible):** Each card represents a security category, features a blue icon, and is prefixed with a red "Very High Risk" badge.
    *   **Categories:** Malware, Data Security - Sharing, Phishing, and Exploit.
    *   **Details:** Each card lists specific associated detection rules (e.g., "Email Message Containing Malicious Item Not Removed After Delivery (Microsoft 365)") and the integrated vendors/platforms.
    *   **Call-to-Action:** A blue button labeled **Create Campaign** is present at the bottom of every card.
*   **Expansion Link:** A "Show More" link is centered below the recommendation cards, indicating further categories are available.

### Section 2: Real-Time Coaching Campaigns

This section provides a management console for existing coaching campaigns.

*   **Header:** Title "Real-Time Coaching Campaigns."
*   **Filtering:** Three selector tabs are available: **Active** (currently selected), Inactive, and All.
*   **Data Table:** A tabular display organizes campaigns with the following columns:
    *   **Campaign Name:** Hyperlinked text (e.g., "Password Safety Coaching").
    *   **Detection Rules:** Lists key rules, often truncated with a "+X more" count (e.g., "+2 more," "+4 more").
    *   **Vendor:** Lists the detection source (e.g., CrowdStrike, Zscaler).
    *   **Status:** Displays the campaign state using a green status badge (e.g., **Active**).
    *   **Actions:** Contains a set of three standard management icons for each row: View (Eye icon), Edit (Pencil icon), and More Options (Vertical Ellipsis icon).
